Himmelsbach | On Pitino's remark and sensitivity

Was Rick Pitino's comment after Savannah State insensitive?

Himmelsbach | On Pitino's remark and sensitivity

Adam Himmelsbach

Adam Himmelsbach, ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com 5:20 p.m. EST November 25, 2014
Buy Photo

Louisville basketbal coach Rick Pitino before before the start of the match-up with visiting Savannah State on Monday evening at the KFC Yum! Center. Nov. 24, 2014(Photo: , Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal)Buy Photo

Tags

  • Savannah State University
  • Rick Pitino
11 CONNECT 14 TWEETLINKEDIN 1 COMMENTEMAILMORE

After Louisville crushed Savannah State on Monday night, 87-26, Cardinals coach Rick Pitino made it clear he took no delight in the stomping. And really, how could you not feel for the Tigers? They were scoreless for the game's first 16 minutes and fell behind 29-0.

Pitino had shown mercy, substituting liberally and giving extensive playing time to walk-ons and seldom-used scholarship players. And at the end of his press conference, when he was asked if he could take any joy in a game like that, he said he couldn't. Then he tried to inject some humor into the situation.

"I tried everything," he said. "I mean, we played four white guys and an Egyptian. We tried everything."

He was referring to walk-ons David Levitch, Dillon Avare and Trent Gilbert, and freshmen scholarship players Matz Stockman and Anas Mahmoud, who is from Egypt.

Video | Watch Rick Pitino's remarks here

Many people in the interview room chuckled, and the press conference ended. I thought the joke was awkward and slightly uncomfortable, though I didn't find it to be offensive.

I was one of many to post the quote on Twitter, and a good number of respondents were critical of Pitino. Then on Tuesday, the comment picked up steam, including a SportsCenter discussion about whether Pitino had gone too far.

I've heard some people say it was a racist comment. I've heard some ask what would have happened if Pitino had switched it around and said that he kept the score low by taking out his black players.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Transcript: Post-Savannah State Q&A with Rick Pitino

Yes, that would have been different. But no, that's not what he said.

Some Kentucky fans have claimed there should be more backlash, because if John Calipari had said what Pitino said, there would have been more backlash. But that's a flimsy argument. If you're fundamentally against what Pitino said, that's fine. But a hypothetical comparison about Calipari is irrelevant here.

RELATED: Post-Savannah State Q&A with Rick Pitino

BLOWOUT WIN: U of L blanks Savannah State early, rolls to W

I didn't address Pitino's comment in my column from Monday night's game, but I was thinking more about it on Tuesday morning. I posted on Twitter that he should ease up on the comedy hour, but that there was no malice in his joke. Some people were stunned to hear that it was even an issue, and others were stunned that Pitino had yet to apologize.

I'm not here to tell you that you should laugh at Pitino's joke or that you should be offended by it. But in our society, whenever race is injected into a conversationjokingly or notit can become sensitive. And moving forward, Pitino will probably be sensitive to that.

Adam Himmelsbach can be reached at 502-582-4372 by email ahimmelsbach@courier-journal.com and on Twitter @adamhimmelsbach

You can watch Pitino's full comments in this video

Louisville basketball coach Rick Pitino discusses the Savannah State blowout on Monday night at the KFC Yum! Center. Pitino said the team would not be reviewing the game film for the first time since he started coaching. Alton Strupp/CJ
